transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Let me see your hands. Let me see your hands. Put down the gun. Put down the weapon now. Do it now. Is this what you want to die doing? Drop the gun. Put your hands behind your back now, sir.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Getting tough as an action hero. That's Tyler Perry in the new film "Alex Cross." It's a very big departure for you, this.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes, yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Never seen you in quite this role. Do you enjoy playing the action hero?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: I actually did. I never thought of it as an action hero, though. When I read the script, I look at his entire arc, and it was very interesting to me. The one thing that made me say no was Morgan Freeman. And --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I mean replacing Morgan Freeman is --

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes, yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: -- is like replacing Sean Connery as Bond or something.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Look, I mean, the man played God. OK? He plays --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: He's my -- he's my movie God.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes, he played God in a movie. So I couldn't -- I'm like -- but as I look at James Patterson's description of the physicality and the age and family, and I thought, he's talking about me. So I gave it a second look and I loved the arc that I get to play in this role. I get to go from a family man to the brilliant psychologist figuring things out, to chasing down a bad guy, to this lion being unleashed at the end of the movie. So I'm super excited about it.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: You're also super slim, Tyler. And we've got here "Men's Health," look at this. You've lost 30 pounds?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes. I dropped 30 pounds.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: This is one of those gut-busting front covers.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: "How Tyler Perry Dropped 30 Pounds, and You Can, Too." But you do it in great

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Mostly I worked with a trainer, a guy Anthony Golston. Great guy. There's a book called "Pray Fit," that really helps with prayer and working out.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: But is it basically about you just don't eat as much?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes, you don't -- you don't eat as much and you move a lot more, and the thing that I was working out and running five miles -- this Krav Maga, Israeli fighting, and I'm tell you, I'm dropping names here, but this guy Eric down in Atlanta who worked with me was amazing at -- I did it for five minutes and couldn't get off the floor. Could not get of the floor. I couldn't get through a whole workout. But it's amazing to get you to really shed the pounds.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Let's talk about love, Tyler.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: No.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Let me ask that again. Let's talk about love, Tyler.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: OK. Fine. Let's talk about love.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: How many times have you been properly in love in your life?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: What does that mean? What does that mean, like --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: That's what Oprah said to me. And I said, you know, the type that makes your heart ache or break. That's what it means. That kind of love.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: If I told you the truth I'd get in trouble so --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Why?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Because there are --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Tyler, Tyler, I'm not letting you off the hook.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: OK. OK. It's just -- all right, all right. Once.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Really?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Once, yes. Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: And what went wrong?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: I think we were both very young. Well, we were mid-30s, which was -- it was a very scary time in my life. I was just coming into success. I had spent 28 years of my life being very unhappy and I was -- I was very afraid of it. I was very afraid of the feeling of not being able to know if she loved me the way that I loved her, and the control I think scared me.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: It was, in the end, your decision to walk away?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes. It was.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Do you regret that?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: No, I don't.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: You thought it was the right thing?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes, because we both were in a place where -- and I just realized I should not have said this because -- I should not have said this.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Why? Why shouldn't you have said it?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Because I said too much. Now she'll figure it out. And -- yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: What will she figure out? She knows what happened.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Why don't you ask another question?

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: This is a fascinating side to you, because you're being so nice about it and so honest.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: OK. All right. So what do you want to talk about now?

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I suppose the obvious question after that is, do you hope to have that again in your life? I mean do -- is -- you're so busy. You're so successful.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Well, that's part of the reason that I'm so busy. Like there's a woman that I'm seeing now that I love very, very much. It's a different kind of love, but I love her very, very much. And --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: OK. Now I'm beginning to work out why you dug yourself into a hole.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: See now --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Yes, I did.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: There it is. So what I'm trying to do at this point is just enjoy it all. I'm not ready to settle down, I'm not ready to get married. I'm not ready to be in a situation where I have a commitment. Not ready for that, and especially after that situation.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Well, I see. So you went through a very deep experience and you just want to be sure next time that it's right.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: And what's the rush?

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: I'm a guy. I'm 43. I've got no biological clock.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: But don't you want little Tylers running around?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes. I want that more than I want to be married, though. So I just have to find a way that I'm OK with that happening.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Well, I wish you luck, Tyler. There's no hurry. You can do what you like. You probably have a queue -- you call them lines over here, don't you. You have a line probably the length of Manhattan of potential suitors, I would imagine.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Well, I appreciate that. OK --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Shall we move on?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes, please. Thank you so much. Wow. All right.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Do you want to have a glass of water?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: No, I felt good. No. I need a shot of vodka, my friend. That's what I need at this point.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I thought I'd ask you one thing. You cast Kim Kardashian in a film about marriage counseling --

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: And then it gets worse.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I mean, seriously. Seriously. I know that may be one of the most awkward links of all time.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: You went from bad to worse. Yes, yes, I did.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: What were you thinking?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: No, no, no, no. Let me just say this. I mean --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Kim Kardashian is to marriage counseling what Bernie Madoff is to financial management.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Let me make this perfectly clear about Kim Kardashian and my choice of casting her in this film. I wrote a film that is coming out in March, and it's called "The Marriage Counselor" and it is about -- it's a cautionary tale about making bad decisions in relationships. I had no idea she was married. I had no idea she was going through what she was going through. I had no idea she was going to go through a divorce.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Did you have any idea who she was?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: To be honest with you, I did not.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: You've never heard of her?

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: I have heard of her, but I didn't know all of that she had done. But what I know about her is this. She's a sweet girl. She came in. She did a great job. She was very professional. I'm very happy with what she did and I'm also very happy that -- of this. And hear me clearly when I say this. There are millions of people who look up to the Kardashians. And I think it's very responsible to have someone like Kim Kardashian in a film that is a cautionary tale about making bad decisions and choices so that as people or children or fans of hers are watching and coming in and they see this story, if it speaks to them, then she's done a great job and I've done a great job in putting her in the movie.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: And by the way, she has about 18 million followers on Twitter.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: So you understand what I'm --

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: I get it. I interviewed her.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes. Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: And her sister. I was impressed by it.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: She hasn't claimed to be anything she's not.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Didn't claim to be fabulously talented. What she is --

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Is beautiful.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: -- very hard working, very beautiful.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Very hard working. Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: And knows to work a brand.

transcript.speaker: Perry
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Morgan
transcript.text: Let's take a little break. Come back and talk about another smart cookie. A fabulously talented one. Whitney Houston. I interviewed her earlier. A tragic loss. And I want to know your thoughts. You were a friend of hers, tried to help her and clearly, like many other people, weren't successful.
